content.body: I'm going to have to look at this more.
however, boxed symbols do not have a [[Description]] internal slot
they instead have a [[SymbolData]] internal slot, which holds the underlying symbol, which is what e.g. `Symbol.prototype.description` uses
content.formatted_body: they instead have a [[SymbolData]] internal slot, which holds the underlying symbol, which is what e.g. Symbol.prototype.description uses

content.body: So it looks like the only way to create a Symbol object is by invoking ToObject on a Symbol value. Is that right?
(e.g., there isn't an analogue to `new Number(3)`)
content.formatted_body: (e.g., there isn't an analogue to new Number(3))

content.body: same deal for BigInts, I think
And referring to `Symbol()` as "the Symbol constructor" is technically correct, but maybe misleading (same with BigInt).
content.formatted_body: And referring to Symbol() as "the Symbol constructor" is technically correct, but maybe misleading (same with BigInt).
